content: ooh everyone why lock here welcome back
speed ease and costs are the names of the game this week as we make some
modular fences for your modern post a pack or sci-fi tabletop games at the
core of this project is cross stitching mesh sometimes referred to as granny
grading this large sheet is like 70 cents from any crafting store also got
some flat black spray primer because the grading is a smooth plastic and
therefore will not hold acrylic craft paint very well we're gonna take this
outside and spray both sides of the mesh then start cutting strips of the mesh at
a 45 degree angle now my cutting mat has some 45 degree guiding lines but if you
don't have that simply measure in both directions from one corner and connect
those two points and you'll have a perfect 45-degree cut as for the width
of the strips well think about how tall you want the fence to be I did one and a
half inches now the basis of these fences will be jumbo popsicle sticks I
thought about using chipboard but these are stronger won't warp and are already
the perfect size and shape so check the lengths depending on the brand it may
vary but it should be around six inches and cut your mesh strips to be that long
and foam board I'm going to cut a bunch of half-inch wide pieces peel the paper
from both sides and then on one side texturize the foam by stabbing at it
with some balled-up aluminum foil then a bead of hot glue on the untextured side
attach the mesh and complete the sandwich with another foam strip then a
healthy bead of hot glue on the Jumbo popsicle stick and attach the fence
now we'll take some white PVA glue like Elmer's coat the base and pour some
pebbles or construction sand on it this is quikrete construction sand has
varying sized aggregate four bucks for a 50-pound bag lifetime supply once that's
dry we're gonna take a metallic gunmetal color this is just a cheap acrylic craft
paint from Michaels so we'll paint that gunmetal on the
fence by the way this is why we primed the mesh first if you spray the primer
on that whole fence it could dissolve the foam even if you protected it with
white glue plus it's quicker and more economical to spray that whole large
sheet of mesh anyway so next would take some plain grey and paint those foam
pieces solid base coat these are gonna be concrete columns at this point I
looked at it and felt the fence was a little bit too bland so I took some
shimmering metallic silver and just roughly attacked the mesh so now I have
two shades of metallic on they're a little more interesting to look at okay
back on track we're gonna make a black wash rough rule of thumb one part black
paint ten parts water and adjust from there then wash the concrete columns
with it it will dry much later so if it goes on kind of dark and pulls up like
this that's fine actually let it do that then for the ground burnt umber just a
dark brown real simple solid coat let all of that dry should take an hour or
two and then take a tan sort of color and dry brush the ground if you're new
to this dry brush just means work most of the paint off the brush back onto
your pallet and then strike at the peace lightly so that catches only the high
detail in this case the sand on the ground
and finally some moss this pack has a sordid moss I'm gonna take some of the
dead tan colored stuff and hot glue some tough tone and we're about to go to the
table look at the finished product but real quick some reminders there's a link
in the description below for my storefront as all the tools and supplies
that I recommend and for all you 3d printers out there while Ochs crafting
goods is sponsored by heroes horde which has an excellent range of high quality
models including but not limited to all true tiles lines which are open lock
compatible also check out my modules over on the DMS guild and remember $3
patrons get free copies of all my releases right here's a completed one I
just did one tuft per fence randomly placed now let's set up a scene I have
some necrons trying to take over a facility that some ultramarines are
defending so we'll throw down in METEC and boom so depending what game you're
playing the rules will be different or you know but the point is this divides
up the scene divides up the battlefield meaningfully effects strategy here's a
fuel depot over in the corner everything you see on here we've done in
previous episodes and I figured I'd throw models down because pretty boring
without that the rounded ends of the bases those jumbo popsicle sticks allows
you to pivot and do you know angles or turns as opposed to a square base come
on on up the middle here a couple squads oh you have a void shield generator
episode 80 if you like that one I left a gap here is an entrance so that like
this is maybe a tactical objective of some kind this other tower here so you
can use the fences to set up these may be where your objective markers go or
something like that like over here I put repair Bay for some dreadnaughts aka I
haven't finished painting them yet so they're laid up for now and the power
station that was a good one so yeah necrons by
the way are my main army I have the others as house armies for when friends
want to play or something like that so again speed ease cost quality obviously
nothing like professional or anything but the whole point is it was like two
hours of work to knock out twenty of these if you liked this particular
project here's two more that you should go check out right now also enjoy this
month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe and click that Bell
reminder icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll see you next time
